_exec_summary.SummaryText:
cluding:
1.	Installed three UR/IR flame detectors to detect for flame at the top of the reformer and the quench pots. The flame detectors will alarm at the HMI when a flame is detected.
2.	Multiple portions of the hydrogen were susceptible to High-Temperature Hydrogen Attack (HTHA) due to the operating temperature and pressure being below the Nelson Curve. Material upgrades were made to the HTS Converter (C-103), the Quench Pot (TK-202), the Waste Heat Boiler (WH-102), the piping between the HTS Converter and the Waste Heat Boiler, and the piping between the Feed Preheater (HX-101) and the HTS Converter to prevent embrittlement of the metal from HTHA.
3.	In April 2019, a rupture occurred at the flex hose closest to the quench pot. The rupture occurred due to a combination of reasons, however, it was determined that this flex hose itself represents a weak point within the H2 process. The new design eliminates this weak point. The downcomer between the Quench Pot (TK-202) and the Feed Preheater (HX-101) will be replaced by a solid piece of piping. Hydrochem, the original process manufacturer, was hired to complete the new downcomer design by ASME B31.3 Code “Process Piping”. The design is similar to the current design, but with the flex hoses removed.
4.	Add a hardwired temperature switch D/S of the quench pot to shut down the FSP at 1000 degrees F. This change was an ARA recommendation to decrease the risk of a high high temperature from damaging the D/S equipment
